Introduction

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), also known as pseudotumor cerebri, is a condition characterized by increased intracranial pressure (ICP) without an underlying intracranial mass lesion or hydrocephalus.

Pathophysiology



The pathophysiology of IIH likely involves increased intracranial venous pressure due to impaired reabsorption of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) by the arachnoid granulations or CSF lymphatic drainage sites; obesity-related increased abdominal and intracranial venous pressure is another proposed mechanism.

Risk factors



Several factors have been identified as increasing the risk of developing IIH, including:



  • Women of childbearing age
  • Obesity (BMI â‰¥30 kg/mÂ²) and/or recent weight gain
  • Use of tetracyclines, vitamin A and its metabolites (eg, retinoids, isotretinoin), and growth hormone (due to various effects on CSF flow or metabolism)

Clinical presentation



The most common signs and symptoms of IIH include:



  • Headache
  • Papilledema
  • Transient visual changes and later in the course permanent vision loss

Headache



Headache is the most common presenting symptom in patients with IIH and can have variable patterns.  Patients typically have a holocranial or lateralized headache; they may have associated nausea and vomiting.  Headaches are classically described as worse during recumbent positioning (eg, at night, upon waking) or straining (eg, bowel movements, heavy lifting), which increase ICP.  Often, the headache of IIH may be similar to, or superimposed on, other primary headache disorders (eg, migraine, tension-type), as well as confounded by headaches associated with obstructive sleep apnea, which is common in obese patients.

Papilledema



The hallmark finding of increased ICP on examination is bilateral symmetric papilledema (

image 1
), which is elevation of the optic discs with blurred disc margins seen on funduscopy.  Increased intracranial pressure is transmitted through the cerebrospinal fluid in the subarachnoid space, which is continuous with the optic nerve sheath; this buildup of pressure compresses the optic nerves externally, which in turn impairs axoplasmic flow within the optic nerves, causing papilledema.

Visual changes



Pressure on the optic nerve and papilledema can cause:



  • Transient vision loss that varies according to changes in head positioning.
  • Gradual, permanent vision loss over time; this is likely due to optic nerve atrophy that occurs due to chronic compression of the optic nerve
  • Enlargement of the physiologic blind spot (
    figure 1
    ), which is present at the location of the (now enlarged) optic nerve head
  • Blurry vision
  • Light flashes
  • Peripheral visual field deficits


In some patients, the increased pressure in IIH can cause cranial nerve palsies; the most commonly affected is the abducens nerve (CN VI) because of its long course through the skull to the lateral rectus muscle.  Patients with CN VI palsy may have diplopia and impaired eye abduction.  Other common findings with IIH include pulsatile tinnitus due to increased vascular pulsations and/or neck pain and stiffness possibly from increased pressure transmitted to cervical nerve sheaths.

Diagnosis



After thorough history and complete ocular examination, if IIH is suspected, the first step in evaluation (

figure 2
) is neuroimaging to exclude other causes of elevated ICP (eg, space-occupying mass).  MRI, often with venography (to rule out cerebral venous thrombosis), is the preferred imaging modality; however, CT scan is generally faster and easier to obtain in emergencies.  Although neuroimaging is primarily obtained to rule out mass lesions, there are some findings that can suggest a diagnosis of IIH including:



  • Empty sella (increased CSF pressure flattening the pituitary and filling the sella space with fluid)
  • Flattening of the posterior sclera due to transmitted pressure onto the posterior side of the globe
  • Narrowing of the venous sinuses, which can lead to decreased CSF drainage capacity and predispose patients to IIH.  This finding is more specific to IIH, in contrast to other causes of increased ICP.


After a space-occupying lesion is excluded, lumbar puncture should be performed.  An opening pressure of >250 mm Hâ‚‚O on lumbar puncture confirms the diagnosis of IIH as long as other cerebrospinal fluid studies (eg, cell counts) are normal, ruling out other secondary causes of increased ICP (eg, infection, tumor).

Differential diagnosis



Several conditions may mimic IIH, including:



  • Brain tumor:  Both IIH and brain tumors can cause increased ICP and similar symptoms.  However, brain tumors are typically associated with other neurological signs and symptoms, such as weakness, numbness, or seizures.  Brain imaging studies, such as MRI or CT scans, will help to differentiate between these two conditions.
  • Meningitis often presents acutely with symptoms of headache and neck stiffness with elevated ICP on lumbar puncture.  However, CSF analysis typically shows some combination of elevated protein concentration, low glucose concentration, and pleocytosis.
  • Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis can also present with headache and signs of increased ICP without obvious head CT findings.  It is associated with prothrombotic conditions and may cause focal neurologic deficits.  If suspected, an MR venography will help differentiate this condition from IIH.
  • Optic neuritis is usually associated with multiple sclerosis, which can occur in young women and cause vision loss.  However, vision loss is typically monocular (vs binocular), and eye pain and an afferent pupillary defect are usually present.
  • Migraines classically cause unilateral, throbbing headaches and photophobia.  Although symptoms of migraine headaches may be indistinguishable from those of IIH, patients with migraine typically do not have papilledema.
  • Temporal arteritis (TA) commonly presents with headache.  Although neck pain may be present from commonly associated polymyalgia rheumatica, TA almost never occurs in patients age <50, constitutional symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss) are common, and increased ICP is not seen.

Management



The main treatment goal for IIH is to reduce ICP to prevent permanent vision loss; treatments can also provide symptomatic relief of headaches and other symptoms.  The management of IIH (

figure 3
) depends on the severity of the symptoms and the risk of vision loss:

Weight loss



Weight loss is the only disease-modifying therapy and is recommended for all patients with obesity and IIH.  For patients with very mild symptoms and without vision deficits it may be the only necessary treatment.

Medications



  • Acetazolamide:  Acetazolamide is first-line medical therapy and is used for patients with concerning visual deficits or debilitating symptoms.  It inhibits choroid plexus carbonic anhydrase, thereby decreasing CSF production and resulting in lower ICP.
  • Topiramate:  Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that also inhibits carbonic anhydrase activity to reduce ICP.  It can be used as an alternative to acetazolamide.

Surgical intervention



Surgery (eg, cerebral venous sinus stenting, ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement, optic nerve fenestration) should be performed in patients with an immediate threat to vision (progressive, sustained loss in visual fields/acuity), or in those with progressive or debilitating symptoms who fail medical therapy with acetazolamide.

Other



Corticosteroids and serial lumbar punctures are sometimes used as a temporary therapy for patients with IIH and severe visual defects in anticipation of definitive surgery.  However, they are not recommended for long-term management given their associated complications.  In addition to the treatments above, medications associated with precipitation of IIH (eg, tetracyclines, isotretinoin) should be stopped and avoided if possible.

Prognosis



The prognosis for IIH is generally good, with most patients experiencing improvement or stabilization with treatment; if the condition is not treated, the risk of permanent vision loss is higher.  Patients who improve on medication can slowly be weaned off.  Some patients have recurrence of symptoms, often with weight gain.

Summary



Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (
